conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks the light from the source, resulting in a dark area on the surface behind the object. The size and shape of the shadow depend on the relative positions and distances between the light source, the object, and the surface.
In the initial scenario, the light source seems to be positioned at some distance from the objects, creating distinct shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
When the light source moves closer to the objects, the shadows will move closer to the objects because the light rays become more parallel to the surface as the source gets closer.
When the light source moves closer to the objects, the shadows will become smaller due to the angle of incidence of the light rays becoming steeper, leading to less elongated shadows.
The shadow cast by the spherical object (Shadow A) will move closer to the sphere and become smaller.
The shadow cast by the cylindrical object (Shadow B) will move closer to the cylinder and decrease in size.
The shadow cast by the flat, circular object (Shadow C) will shift closer to the object and reduce in size.
The shadow cast by the rectangular object with a grid pattern (Shadow D) will move closer to the object and shrink.
The second image shows that the shadows have moved closer to the objects and are smaller compared to their original positions in the first image.
If the light source moves forward, above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will all move closer to their respective objects and decrease in size.
